message_1: Suppose that $f(z) = \frac{1}{1+z^2}$ is a complex-valued function. Find the Fourier transform of $f(z)$, given by $$\hat{f}(\xi) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(z)e^{-i\xi z}~dz.$$
message_2:
To find the Fourier transform of the given function, we first rewrite the function $f(z)$ as a product of two complex functions:

$$f(z) = \frac{1}{(z - i)(z + i)}$$

Now, we compute the Fourier transform:

$$\hat{f}(\xi) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{(z - i)(z + i)}~dz$$

To evaluate this integral, we use the method of complex contour integration. We consider two cases: $\xi > 0$ and $\xi < 0$.

Case 1: $\xi > 0$

For $\xi > 0$, we close the contour in the upper half-plane. The only singularity enclosed by the contour is the pole at $z = i$. By the residue theorem, we have:

$$\hat{f}(\xi) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot 2\pi i\cdot\text{Res}\left(\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{(z - i)(z + i)}, z=i\right)$$

The residue of the function at $z = i$ is given by:

$$\text{Res}\left(\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{(z - i)(z + i)}, z=i\right) = \lim_{z\to i}\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{z + i} = \frac{e^{\xi}}{2i}$$

Thus, for $\xi > 0$:

$$\hat{f}(\xi) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot 2\pi i\cdot\frac{e^{\xi}}{2i} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{\xi}$$

Case 2: $\xi < 0$

For $\xi < 0$, we close the contour in the lower half-plane. The only singularity enclosed by the contour is the pole at $z = -i$. By the residue theorem, we have:

$$\hat{f}(\xi) = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot 2\pi i\cdot\text{Res}\left(\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{(z - i)(z + i)}, z=-i\right)$$

The residue of the function at $z = -i$ is given by:

$$\text{Res}\left(\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{(z - i)(z + i)}, z=-i\right) = \lim_{z\to -i}\frac{e^{-i\xi z}}{z - i} = -\frac{e^{-\xi}}{2i}$$

Thus, for $\xi < 0$:

$$\hat{f}(\xi) = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot 2\pi i\cdot\left(-\frac{e^{-\xi}}{2i}\right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-\xi}$$

Combining both cases, we get the Fourier transform of $f(z)$:

$$\hat{f}(\xi) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\begin{cases}
e^{\xi}, & \xi > 0 \\
e^{-\xi}, & \xi < 0
\end{cases}$$
